metadata.case_name: Jagirdar of Ramwarm Chandam Palli v. State of Hyderabad
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeals Nos. 392 of 1956 and 686 of 1957

facts.text: Appellant was a Jagirdar holding jagirs Ramwarm Chandam Palli and Gulla Palli, Taluq Sirsalla, District of Karimnagar in the State of Hyderabad.
After Police Action in August 1948, Major General Chaudary appointed Military Governor for the State of Hyderabad.
Nizam of Hyderabad invested Military Governor with authority to administer the State by Farman dated September 19, 1948.
Farman stated: 'all authority for the administration of the State now vests in him' and enjoined obedience.
Nizam issued explanatory Farman on August 7, 1949, declaring that authority includes authority to make Regulations.
Military Governor promulgated Hyderabad Abolition of Jagirs Regulation of 1358 Fasli on August 10, 1949, brought into force August 15, 1949.
Section 5 directed jagirdars to make over management to Jagir Administrator from notified date, or forcible possession.
Section 6: Jagirs included in Diwani, powers of jagirdars cease, exercisable by Jagir Administrator; no recovery of dues.
Section 14: Jagirdars to receive interim maintenance allowances until commutation determined.
Possession of jagirs taken over in September 1949 by Jagir Administrator.
Nizam issued Farman on December 1, 1949, terminating Military Governor, appointing K. Vellodi as Chief Minister with all powers of administration vested in Military Governor.
Chief Minister promulgated Hyderabad Jagirs Commutation Regulation No. XXV of 1359 Fasli, operative January 25, 1950.
Section 3 of Commutation Regulation prescribed method of computing commutation sum.
Inauguration of Constitution of India on January 26, 1950; Hyderabad became part of Union of India.
President certified Abolition and Commutation Regulations under Article 31(6) on April 25, 1950.
Constitution First Amendment Act on June 18, 1951, incorporated Articles 31A, 31B and Sch. IX; Regulations included in Sch. IX.
Appellant filed writ petition in Hyderabad High Court on January 29, 1951, for mandamus to hand over possession, declare Regulations ultra vires.
Petition amended on August 14, 1952, claiming ss. 4(1)(c), 4(2) of Commutation Regulation and s. 6(4) of Abolition Regulation invalid as naked confiscation and colourable exercise.
Hyderabad High Court rejected petition on March 31, 1954, certified under Art. 133(1)(c) for appeal.

legal_issues.text: Whether legislative authority was conferred upon the Military Governor by the Farman dated September 19, 1948.
If legislative authority was delegated to the Military Governor by the Farman, whether it was circumscribed by any limitations or reservations.

petitioner_arguments.text: Abolition Regulation and Commutation Regulation ultra vires and unconstitutional.
Sections 4(1)(c), 4(2) of Commutation Regulation and s. 6(4) of Abolition Regulation invalid as naked confiscation and colourable/fraudulent exercise of legislative power.
Farman dated September 19, 1948 conferred only executive authority, not legislative.
Farman merely recited authority, did not invest it.

respondent_arguments.text: Farman conferred all authority including legislative; explanatory Farman confirms power to make Regulations.
Nizam was absolute ruler; delegation full sovereign authority; no withdrawal before Regulations.

court_reasoning.text: By plain words of Farman dated September 19, 1948, all authority for administration conferred on Military Governor, encompassing entirety of sovereign authority including legislative.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Expression 'all authority for the administration' includes legislative powers.

court_reasoning.text: Explanatory Farman dated August 7, 1949 expressly includes authority to make Regulations.
Nizam absolute ruler; delegation not extinguishing sovereignty but full during tenure; no evidence of withdrawal or inconsistent orders before Abolition Regulation.
Doctrine of colourable legislation applies only to legislatures with constitutional restrictions; not to absolute sovereign delegate.
Chief Minister had same amplitude of power; Commutation Regulation valid.
Rights extinguished pre-Constitution; no revival; certified under Art. 31(6); included in Sch. IX by 1st Amendment.

holdings.text: Farman dated September 19, 1948 conferred full sovereign authority including legislative on Military Governor.
No limitations on delegated authority; Abolition and Commutation Regulations validly promulgated.
Regulations not colourable; no infringement of fundamental rights post-1st Amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Keshavan Madhava Menon v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Constitution has no retrospective operation; rights extinguished pre-Constitution not revived.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certification of Regulations; inclusion in Sch. IX immunizes from Part III challenge; no retrospective effect.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Abolition of Jagirs Regulation, 1358 Fasli
statutes_cited.relevance: Abolished jagirs, took possession, interim allowances; challenged as invalid.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Jagirs Commutation Regulation No. XXV of 1359 Fasli
statutes_cited.relevance: Computed commutation sum; challenged as naked confiscation.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (First Amendment) Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Incorporated Arts. 31A, 31B and Sch. IX including the Regulations.

outcome.summary: The appeals challenging the validity of the Hyderabad Abolition of Jagirs Regulation and Jagirs Commutation Regulation as ultra vires, unconstitutional, and colourable legislation were dismissed. The Court held the Regulations were validly promulgated under delegated sovereign authority and protected by constitutional amendments.

key_quotes.text: 'all authority for the administration of the State now vests in him'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key phrase in Farman conferring full authority including legislative.

key_quotes.text: the authority ... includes and has always included authority to make Regulations.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: a statute enacted by a legislative authority whose powers are not fettered by any constitutional or other limitations, cannot be declared invalid as enacted in colourable exercise of its powers.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects colourable legislation plea against sovereign delegate.
